G.L. c. 212, \u00a7 3.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction over this action pursuant to G.L. c. 212, § 3, as this is a civil action sounding in tort with damages within the jurisdictional limits of the District Court.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7 1.proposition: Venue is proper in this Court under G.L. c. 223, § 1, because the cause of action arose in this judicial district and the Defendant resides here.

*Anderson v. Mass. Port Auth.*, 20 Mass..raw_text: *Anderson v. Mass. Port Auth.*, 20 Mass. App. Ct. 148, 151 (1985).
*Anderson v. Mass. Port Auth.*, 20 Mass..proposition: Defendant owed a duty of reasonable care to park users, including the Plaintiff, to control his dog and comply with applicable leash requirements.
*Anderson v. Mass. Port Auth.*, 20 Mass..support_reasoning: The opinion concerns premises liability and negligent provision of an unsafe ladder to a window cleaner on an apartment complex job site, not duties related to control of dogs or compliance with leash laws. The court holds that Paul and DLP owed a duty to take reasonable steps to prevent injury on the premises and, having undertaken to supply a ladder, to supply a safe one. There is no discussion of animals, parks, dog control, or leash requirements, so this case does not support the specific dog-control duty proposition stated.
*Anderson v. Mass. Port Auth.*, 20 Mass..relevant_excerpt: “It could be found that Paul, as owner of the complex, and DLP, as Paul’s agent at the time of the accident on April 8, 1975, had sufficient control over the complex, to make it the duty of each of them to take ‘reasonable and appropriate’ steps to prevent injury to persons lawfully on the premises of the complex regardless of the status entitling such persons to be there. … If, however, these defendants undertook to supply a ladder to Searcy, it was their duty to supply one which was safe.”

*Mounsey v. Ellard*, 363 Mass. 693, 707.proposition: Defendant’s duty arose both under common law principles of negligence (*Mounsey v. Ellard*, 363 Mass. 693, 707 (1973)), and specific statutory obligations requiring dog owners to restrain their animals in public spaces, including G.L. c. 140, §§ 155, 173, and 174.
*Mounsey v. Ellard*, 363 Mass. 693, 707.support_reasoning: The provided excerpt from Mounsey v. Ellard is a concurring opinion discussing the abandonment of the invitee/licensee distinction and the treatment of trespassers in premises liability. It does not address duties arising from dog owner liability, restraint of animals, or the cited Massachusetts statutes (G.L. c. 140, §§ 155, 173, 174). Nor does it specifically articulate that the defendant’s duty in that case arose under both common-law negligence and those dog-control statutes. Therefore, this citation does not support the specific proposition claimed.
*Mounsey v. Ellard*, 363 Mass. 693, 707.relevant_excerpt: "The court holds that the measure of responsibility of an occupier should no longer depend on whether the injured person is characterized as a ‘licensee’ rather than an ‘invitee,’ or vice versa; the question is to turn on other, more vital factors."

G.L. c. 140, \u00a7\u00a7 155, 173, and.proposition: Defendant’s duty arose both under common law principles of negligence (*Mounsey v. Ellard*, 363 Mass. 693, 707 (1973)), and specific statutory obligations requiring dog owners to restrain their animals in public spaces, including G.L. c. 140, §§ 155, 173, and 174.

*Jesionek v. Massachusetts Port Auth.*,.proposition: Defendant’s failure to control his dog was a direct and foreseeable cause of Plaintiff’s injuries.
*Jesionek v. Massachusetts Port Auth.*,.support_reasoning: The case does address proximate cause and foreseeability where a defendant’s failure to secure an instrumentality (a forklift) leads to injury through the intervening conduct of a third party. However, it has nothing to do with control of a dog or animal, and the factual and doctrinal context is unsecured machinery on commercial premises. Using this case to support a proposition about a defendant’s failure to control his dog causing plaintiff’s injuries is therefore inaccurate and out of context.
*Jesionek v. Massachusetts Port Auth.*,.relevant_excerpt: “The general rule is that ‘[t]he act of a third person, intervening and contributing a condition necessary to the injurious effect of the original negligence, will not excuse the first wrongdoer, if such act ought to have been foreseen. The original negligence still remains a culpable and direct cause of the injury.’… It was thus reasonably foreseeable that the forklift, when left unsecured… would be operated by unauthorized persons… [and] that unauthorized operation would likely cause harm to persons known to pass through the area….”

*Leavitt v. Brockton Hosp., Inc.*, 454 M.proposition: The risk of harm from an unleashed large dog charging a pedestrian is foreseeable, and Defendant’s conduct created a zone of danger that caused Plaintiff’s injuries.
*Leavitt v. Brockton Hosp., Inc.*, 454 M.support_reasoning: The case does not involve a dog, nor does it concern a landowner’s or defendant’s duty arising from a charging animal or similar ‘zone of danger.’ Instead, the court holds that the hospital owed no duty to the plaintiff police officer and that his injuries were outside the scope of foreseeable risk arising from releasing a sedated patient. The opinion thus limits foreseeability and scope-of-liability to harms directly related to the initial risk, and does not support the proposition that the risk from a large unleashed dog charging a pedestrian is foreseeable or that such conduct creates a compensable zone of danger to that pedestrian.
*Leavitt v. Brockton Hosp., Inc.*, 454 M.relevant_excerpt: “The law does not impose liability for all harm factually caused by tortious conduct. Liability for conduct obtains only where the conduct is both a cause in fact of the injury and where the resulting injury is within the scope of the foreseeable risk arising from the negligent conduct. … While a third party nonpatient directly injured by a medicated patient who drives an automobile from a hospital may be within the scope of foreseeable risk, a police officer injured in an accident in which the patient is not involved is outside that scope.”

*Jupin v. Kask*, 447 Mass. 141, 147\u201.proposition: A reasonable person exercising due care would have maintained physical control over the dog to prevent precisely the kind of incident that occurred.
*Jupin v. Kask*, 447 Mass. 141, 147\u201.support_reasoning: The case concerns a homeowner’s duty to exercise reasonable care in securing firearms stored in her home against access by a mentally unstable, violent person with unsupervised entry. It does not involve dogs, animal control, or any analogous discussion of maintaining physical control over a dog to prevent an incident. Therefore, citing Jupin v. Kask for a proposition about due care in controlling a dog misstates the subject and holding of the case.
*Jupin v. Kask*, 447 Mass. 141, 147\u201.relevant_excerpt: "In consideration of emerging social customs and values, as well as appropriate social policy, we hold that a homeowner who permits a guest to keep guns permanently on her premises and allows a third person with a criminal history and mental difficulties unsupervised access to the property, has a duty to ensure that the firearms are properly and safely stored."

*S.C.M. Corp. v. Cox*, 409 Mass. 505, 51.proposition: Defendant’s negligence was the factual and proximate cause of Plaintiff’s injuries.
*S.C.M. Corp. v. Cox*, 409 Mass. 505, 51.support_reasoning: The opinion is a Massachusetts criminal case about evidentiary errors in a child sexual assault prosecution. It does not analyze negligence, causation, or any tort concepts concerning whether a defendant’s negligence was the factual and proximate cause of a plaintiff’s injuries. Accordingly, it provides no authority for that causation proposition and appears to be an inapposite citation for that purpose.
*S.C.M. Corp. v. Cox*, 409 Mass. 505, 51.relevant_excerpt: The opinion discusses evidentiary issues, fresh complaint doctrine, and indictment specificity in a criminal sexual assault case, but contains no discussion of negligence or proximate cause. There is no relevant passage addressing causation in a civil negligence context.

*Ryder v. Robinson*, 369 Mass. 174, 178.proposition: Plaintiff’s decision to evade the dog was a natural and reasonable response to Defendant’s negligence.
*Ryder v. Robinson*, 369 Mass. 174, 178.case_name: Commissioners of Civil Service v. Municipal Court
*Ryder v. Robinson*, 369 Mass. 174, 178.support_reasoning: The opinion is a civil service / administrative review decision about the discharge of a Boston patrolman; it does not involve a dog, negligence, or a plaintiff’s evasive conduct. Nothing in the court’s reasoning discusses personal injury, proximate cause, or the reasonableness of a plaintiff’s reaction to a defendant’s negligence. The cited case therefore cannot provide authority for the proposition about a plaintiff’s decision to evade a dog being a natural and reasonable response to negligence.
*Ryder v. Robinson*, 369 Mass. 174, 178.relevant_excerpt: No excerpt in this opinion addresses dogs, negligence, or a plaintiff’s evasive conduct; the case concerns review of a Civil Service Commission decision upholding the discharge of a police officer for conduct unbecoming an officer.

*Kosko v. Hines*, 201 Mass. 456, 458 (19.proposition: The fact that the dog did not physically contact Plaintiff does not absolve Defendant of liability, as emotional and physical injuries sustained while reasonably avoiding danger caused by Defendant’s negligence are compensable.
*Kosko v. Hines*, 201 Mass. 456, 458 (19.support_reasoning: Nothing in this opinion concerns dogs, physical contact, negligence, or recovery for emotional or physical injuries while avoiding danger. The case is about municipal authority, taxpayer standing, and the validity and ratification of a town’s waterworks purchase and bond issuance. It therefore does not address, much less establish, the proposition regarding liability without physical contact from a dog.
*Kosko v. Hines*, 201 Mass. 456, 458 (19.relevant_excerpt: The plaintiffs, while seeking to prevent an unlawful expenditure of the public funds, do not represent other taxpayers, nor are they authorized to act for the town. If by reason of alleged misrepresentations or constructive fraud on the part of the company, or of its officers or agents while lawfully acting for it, a right of rescission exists, it can be exercised, if at all, only by the town which was the other party to a bilateral contract.

*Glidden v. Maglio, Inc.*, 430 Mass. 694.proposition: Defendant’s negligence was the direct and proximate cause of Plaintiff’s medical expenses, lost wages, pain and suffering, and emotional distress.
*Glidden v. Maglio, Inc.*, 430 Mass. 694.support_reasoning: The case does not support the proposition that the defendant’s negligence was the direct and proximate cause of the plaintiffs’ damages. Instead, the court affirms summary judgment for the defendant precisely because the plaintiffs failed to establish causation, finding no evidence linking any breach of duty by the defendant to the injuries suffered. The opinion is therefore contrary authority on the causation element, not supporting authority.
*Glidden v. Maglio, Inc.*, 430 Mass. 694.relevant_excerpt: “With respect to each such claim, the plaintiffs bear the burden of proving that the defendant committed a breach of the duty to use reasonable care, that the plaintiffs suffered actual loss, and that the defendant’s negligence caused their loss. … The plaintiffs … cannot establish any causal link between their injuries and the defendant’s breach of any duty to them as either homeowner or general contractor, or because of any failure to warn of any purported defect on his property.”

*Whitinsville Plaza, Inc. v. Kotseas*, 3.proposition: Defendant’s negligence was the direct and proximate cause of Plaintiff’s medical expenses, lost wages, pain and suffering, and emotional distress.
*Whitinsville Plaza, Inc. v. Kotseas*, 3.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns enforcement of anticompetitive real covenants, contract rights, and Chapter 93A claims arising out of commercial deed restrictions on land use. It does not involve negligence, personal injury, medical expenses, lost wages, pain and suffering, or emotional distress, nor does it discuss proximate cause of such damages. Therefore, it does not provide authority for the proposition that a defendant’s negligence was the proximate cause of a plaintiff’s medical and related damages.
*Whitinsville Plaza, Inc. v. Kotseas*, 3.relevant_excerpt: These are civil actions commenced by Whitinsville Plaza, Inc. (Plaza), against Charles H. Kotseas and Paul Kotseas (Kotseas) and against Whitinsville CVS, Inc. (CVS). In its further amended complaint against Kotseas, Plaza alleged imminent violations of certain anticompetitive deed restrictions and requested declaratory, injunctive, and monetary relief under theories of breach of contract and unfair acts or practices within the meaning of G. L. c. 93A, § 2... We hold that dismissal for failure to state a claim was erroneous as to some counts of each complaint.

*McNamara v. Honeyman*, 406 Mass. 43, 45.proposition: Defendant’s negligence was the direct and proximate cause of Plaintiff’s medical expenses, lost wages, pain and suffering, and emotional distress.
*McNamara v. Honeyman*, 406 Mass. 43, 45.support_reasoning: The case discusses negligence, causation, and damages in a wrongful death/medical malpractice context, but it does not contain a holding or explicit statement that the defendant’s negligence was the direct and proximate cause of the plaintiff’s medical expenses, lost wages, pain and suffering, and emotional distress. Instead, it addresses whether evidence supported a finding that the psychiatrist’s negligence was a proximate cause of the decedent’s death and whether the Commonwealth was liable under the Tort Claims Act. It therefore does not serve as authority for the specific damages-causation formulation in the proposition.
*McNamara v. Honeyman*, 406 Mass. 43, 45.relevant_excerpt: "The Commonwealth, as a public employer, is liable under G.L.c. 258, § 2, if the jury reasonably found that there was a duty owed to Karen, that there was a breach of such duty by Honeyman, that injury resulted from the breach and that a causal connection existed between the breach and the injury. Dinsky v. Framingham, 386 Mass. 801, 804 (1982)."

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7\u00a7 6B and 85.proposition: Plaintiff is entitled to recover all damages actually sustained and allowed under Massachusetts law.

*Brune v. Belinkoff*, 354 Mass. 102, 109.proposition: Plaintiff is entitled to recover all damages actually sustained and allowed under Massachusetts law.
*Brune v. Belinkoff*, 354 Mass. 102, 109.support_reasoning: The opinion in Brune v. Belinkoff concerns the proper standard of care in medical malpractice cases and expressly overrules the locality rule from Small v. Howard. It does not discuss the measure or scope of damages recoverable by a successful plaintiff, nor does it state that a plaintiff is entitled to recover all damages actually sustained under Massachusetts law. Using this case as authority for that damages proposition misattributes its holding and reasoning.
*Brune v. Belinkoff*, 354 Mass. 102, 109.relevant_excerpt: "The proper standard is whether the physician, if a general practitioner, has, exercised the degree of care and skill of the average qualified practitioner, taking into account the advances in the profession. In applying this standard it is permissible to consider the medical resources available to the physician as one circumstance in determining the skill and care required. ... One holding himself out as a specialist should be held to the standard of care and skill of the average member of the profession practising the specialty, taking into account the advances in the profession."

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7\u00a7 6B and 6C.proposition: Award interest and costs pursuant to G.L. c. 231, §§ 6B and 6C;
